CatDescriptText: Myra Hill, housewife, 1832 Runnette Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, April 4, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that theatrical productions like 'The Green Pastures,' which 'take-off' on religions, should be presented as entertainment?" answer reads: "I think that 'Green Pastures' was blasphemy. I objected to the use of the Negro dialect and the fact that the cast was all Negro.  Also, I especially did not like such parts as the 'God' who was not sure of himself concerning whether or they 'firmament' or whatever the drink was, was 'strong enough.'"
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Myra Hill wearing light colored coat with dark plush collar, light colored hat, and light colored knitted gloves, standing in front of building with sign on door reading "National Slovak Society of the U.S.A."
